Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I haven't watched it yet for some reason...I will watch it soon. By looking at this trailer the sh_t seems gritty as hell, which means it is probably a close representation of what it was actually like to be there (God bless our fallen soldiers from WWII - and all of our wars to be honest).


I applaud Gibson and everyone else who was a part of this film - especially the actor playing the main character. As for the real life soldier who actually DID this???? I am humbled by the fact that he existed in this same life and reality as I do, but that I could never measure up to him... I salute that  man.


I have NO PROBLEM going into battle or marching straight into the jaws of certain death. I've had some experiences in my life that make me the first guy to volunteer for whatEVER suicide mission is at hand and is needed to help us survive. I have zero fear of death. I can tell you that, because I used to be a boy in life and the kind of person we all start as, where when the going gets tough, and some sh_t comes up that NOone wants to do and probably won't came back from....we would hope we didn't get picked for that mission lol. I remember being that person and what it felt like and I can guaranTEE you that TODAY? NO ONE could ever even be CAPABLE of keeping me from being the first man in line to go do some sh_t that everyone else is too scared to do.


I'm a real man our here. All the little boys can take notes. As for THIS soldier.... This guy is about 100,000 times the man I am, because he wouldn't fire a weapon. By God if I need to go over some hill and kill me some enemies, you strap me up with the right guns and ammo, and you can't stop me from going after that target. I refuse to die a coward. A death while being brave is all I yearn for in this life and will probably be denied it since I'm a civilian now (used to be in the military).


To have the balls to march into battle with NO WEAPON in hand.....and refusing to fire a weapon....I take my hat off and bow down to this man. He redefines brave. Honestly, I suspect he wasn't even all human....the level of power and bravery he exhibited must be on the level of immortal angels walking the face of the earth. I bow down.....

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
The portrayal of violence in this film completely undermined the themes. This should have been a grittier film. The battle sequences felt like the musings of someone with a romanticised image of war, or rather someone actively trying to communicate the horrors of war but failing miserably.

The rest of the movie is very effective, but you know what I bet didn't happen? I bet that an American soldier dropped into battle for the first time in his life didn't grab the half-torso of a dead comrade, and use the corpse as a shield in one hand while he mowed down Japanese troops with an assault rifle in the other.

It felt so out-of-place and inauthentic.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
This movie has made history, we will never know what their eyes have seen but this movie  really has captured the evil, sadness, pain and love of war. 
I wish Desmond Doss was alive today  just so I could hug him.
Those 75 men who should have died, lived on, had family and their families had families so on, this man wasn't a hero, he was a saint. And don't forget that he wasn't the only one.
*SPOILER* During the movie, when he became friends with the soldier that kicked him, reminded me of a story my grandfather told me when I was a young boy. I asked him about war, wanting to know his story. He laughed and said "even your father wasn't brave enough to ask that, but since you asked, heres some tips. He said don't make friends in war. I asked why? He said I had 2 best friends, we went through allot, and one morning we had to run up a beach. My friend on the left got his face shot off, and my friend on the right got shot down like a dog" Then he said "Don't be a hero" Funny that, He was a war hero.
Those words stuck with me forever. Love you granddad. Lost but never forgotten.
He only got shot once, and that was by his own man, shot on the back capturing a village in france, He crawled onto a road and a medic drove past, the medic got out, and refused to help him, shortly later another medic came, and drove him 2 the hospital close to the village they we're capturing. after he had healed, he went to the pub of the village they had just captured and seen the medic who left him and he took his pistol out and almost shot him had it not been for another man pushing his hand up. He never slept properly, I remember hearing his screams in his sleep. I never knew what he went through because allot of it he never said, but who would? Just watching this is a small eye opener. Brave brave men and women.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I rate this film a 8/10
Hacksaw ridge is a great film, not the best war film though as it did have that Hollywood touch to it for example the cliff wasnâ€™t as dramatic as it actually was or is. It is a great film though and the history behind it is brutal but beautiful. Lots of people do think that saving private Ryan is the best war film ever. No. The first 15 mins are the best I have ever seen, but the rest of the film just loses it for me. No war film is perfect, hacksaw ridge is a great film but not perfect. A perfect world War 1/2 film for me would be one that is historically perfect, visually perfect and a story that most normal people have never heard of before. Also no dramatic shots, so the only time you can see the opposing solider is when the main characters can. You also can only see just over the trench. Also no disrespect but I am tried of American solider movies, a British or French or even a german army perspective would be more fresh. Maybe even have two perspectives from a allied and axis view. I am trying to create a discussion from people who know there stuff. This was a fantastic film and Desmond was a hero that we all should look up to.

Comment: I just finished watching this movie  about half an hour ago, and I was so inspired. I'm a Christian, but lately I've been in a fairly rough time, and I haven't been feeling God there the whole time. I KNOW  He's always there, whether you can feel Him right next to you or not. I guess I've just been avoiding Him and not trusting. He's been telling me to come back, but I needed a bit of motivation. I had tried one night this week, but I just wasn't feeling it. This movie was exactly the kind of encouragement I needed. God helped me. He brought me back and showed me the way. The movie was about trusting God, especially through the hardest times. I'm going to do my best to stay committed this time. And this time, I'll really have God on my side.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: This was a really good war movie, and an incredible true story. The fact that this man saved so many lives without firing a single bullet, astonishes me. For those who thought that this movie glorified violence in war, it does not. It really shows the brutal realisticness of how horrifying war is. Also, the acting in the movie is really good, but nothing spectacular. Vince Vaughn did surprise me though. I had no idea he was in this movie, because I didn't watch the trailer before I saw the movie. He was funny at times, but it was nice to see his serious, dramatic side that he hasn't shown in a long while. All in all, I give this movie 7.7/10 stars. ğŸ¬ğŸ¥ğŸ’¥ğŸ”«ğŸ”«ğŸ’£ğŸ’‰ğŸ’Š

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
There is some weird stuff about this guys story. When he fas fastening the net to the ridge which was constantly being hailed with gunfire, the other soldiers remember there was no gunfire at all while Doss was up there which was VERY odd.
One Japanese survivor recognized Doss when His story started to go around and attests he remembers him well because every time he had this man (Doss) in his sight and pulled the trigger - his gun jammed. Also, Doss managed 75 men over about 12 hours - equaling about one man every 10 minutes which sounds humanly impossible. One soldier remembers Doss coming back carrying TWO men - one with each arm - and Doss was not a muscular guy! This is one weird story...

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Well in contrary to most peope here I do not think this movie was a masterpiece, neither is it one of the "best films ever made" nor does it deserve an Oscar. While Desmond DossÂ´ story is indeed a quiet unique and moving one and the main actor delivers a great performance, the rest of the movie just represents the pale generic American war movie youÂ´ve seen a dozen times already + a portion of GibsonÂ´s beloved violence. I have to shake my head when I hear people here telling "woah the war scenes were sooo real" which is a dilletantic statement just because visual violence plays a big role. Gibson just created a over-the-top point blank gore fest with gibs flying everywhere around and effects ala Michael Bay instead to potray the true horror of war on a more deep level and perhaps also for both sides (how Refreshing would that be!). Also makes the movie from a military tactical/strategical viewpoint absolutely zero sense, which is especially true for the Japanese side. And eventually - like in your typical AmericaÂ´s hero war movie - you of course have a total dehumanizing and demonization of the enemy - the Japanese who are potrayed like blood-lusting animals constantly busy to do blatant and nasty stuff just in order to serve as a vehicle for American heroic deeds.

If youÂ´ve felt also unsatisfied after watching this movie but are looking for a great movie about the Pacific theatre IÂ´ll recommend you to watch Letters from Iwo Jima which does a great job on the potrayal of good and evil on both sides in war and also The Thin Red Line which is famous not just for its cinematography and psychological aspect but also for the "Battle for Hill 210" the first combat scene in the movie which is one of the most realistic war scenes ever created in film.

Comment:
Just watched it earlier on today, as the film only just came out in my local cinema for the Oscars ceremony, but my God, is it one of the greatest war films ever created, in my opinion. It's pretty much perfect in every way, and I literally cannot think of a single negative thing about the film.

At the very end, the people in the cinema - including myself - all applauded. We didn't just applaud the film, however, but we applauded Desmond Doss and his true heroism and selfless acts of courage in the face of battle.

75 men saved without even holding a firearm or killing a single man. A true hero...

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I honestly didn't care for this film. Sure, the story is incredible, but so many things in this film are just flat-out unrealistic and bad. All the battle sequences, the way the Japanese are portrayed and the forced romance combined with shitty and forgettable characters really brought it down for me. Sorry but you can't hold half a mans corpse in one hand and mow down 20 soldiers with a fully loaded BAR in the other, like what the fuck was I watching Rambo?

Sorry I like the story and the exploration on religious themes, but it was littered  with tons of inaccuracies that break the immersion, it reminded me a lot of "The Patriot" which completely shit on the British and making them look very unrealistic, again, propaganda at best.

Comment:
On Veterans day I took the family to see Mel Gibson's "Hacksaw Ridge" about the 96th and the 77th fight on  Kakazu ridge Okinawa. The boys in the 77th are marching to the battle front. trucks stacked with the body of the boys from the 96th drive past, my heart sank. I was born in the 96th, the boys held and kissed me, many would never have a son.  Doss  saved a lot more than 75, he blessed his company many times and they didn't loose a boy. they delayed attacks to be blessed. read the true story. . Mel didn't have time to tell the whole story. a month of battle. 3 mortar burst a second.  70 machine gun cross fire. crawling in  a mire of blood, shit and guts.  about 25 medal of honor on Okinawa and many hundred more deserved. 
My father came home wounded. Grandmothers lover Erne Pyle was killed. I joined UDT (SEALS) at 17 how stupid.  I have stopped so many boys from going. My own grandson wouldn't listen and lost a leg. it's in a mans dna to fight, how will we ever be able to stop war?

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: The best war movie since Saving Private Ryan...even if your not a fan of war movies this is one heck of an uplifting and inspirational true story -directed brilliantly by Mel Gibson. I was a bit apprehensive of the casting of everyones favourite geek Andrew Garfield in the lead role-but to no avail-Garfield gives an Oscar winning performance taking us through every emotion possible. It takes a while till we get to the battle scenes-but that's essential for us to get to know and feel for the characters.The battle scenes when they hit are like a gore-fest horror movie and are expertly staged. A tremendous uplifting and inspirational movie which is not to be missed.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: Follow your brain.Not your heart! Not your religion. Your BRAIN. A battlefield medic's position during the days of WWII was an illusion, giving the circumstances their instructions were to treat the minor injuries that are not life threatening, the other half of the majority who were doomed were given morphine to ease their sufferings and let them fade away painlessly. That is what the main purpose of the battlefield medic was, to help to unburden dying soldiers from pain and help them die in peace instead in agony, that was the whole purpose of the battlefield medics during WWII warfare, not to cure the dying but to relieve. There were no choppers that can fly to the battlefield take the wounded and fatally shot to the military tent base hospital for treatment, no sir, there was no such luxury available back then. The main character is blind about so many things. It doesn't matter what you gonna do when you're sent in the shit, priest, medic, photo-journalist that covers the war, you'll need to fire a weapon in basic camp to wake up your self instinct for survival and defend yourself.  He should have become a battlefield priest if he's so religious, yes, those positions existed in the army back in the WWII days, not sure about now. Basically the battlefield priest is suppose to read your prayers or listen to you praying while you're dying so you can make peace with god.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: To think that this really happened is amazing. How Doss had the nerve and balls to go back and save half the company on the ridge is insane. And to the people saying that this is faked Hollywood then you're wrong. Mel Gibson got everything right with the Battle of Okinawa, the non-stop mortar shells, the close combat, the gore, the Banzai charges, and the actual fact that the Americans had to retreat and get off the ridge in order to avoid a complete massacre. 10/10 film, go and see it and it will leave you in awe.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
When the movie ended, my hard was beating like a drum! I felt a bit proud to be a Seventh day Adventist, like Desmond Doss was. And I remembered my grandfather, who also was in the WW2 as a medic in the front line of battles (in Finland against Russia), but never got injured. He was protected supernaturally. He heard a warning voice, when he was in a dangerous place.

I warmly recommend the movie in spite of the graphical nature of war scenes. A good reminder, who is really in charge of this world.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: If you haven't seen this movie then don't bother writing an ignorant comment on what you think this film does or does not represent. If you have seen this movie, then I know you understand the sheer hell these men endured in an effort to combat an evil empire. The graphic nature of this film will shake you to the core. In the first ten minutes of actual on screen warfare you will experience a fear you have never felt before. Hacksaw ridge is a place no man should be forced to enter. It is kill zone of the like which no Hollywood bullshit entity has dared trespass on film. Because it makes them and their audience uncomfortable. Because it shows the real darkness of our world. It took a real hero to lead us through that hell. And it took a recovering alcoholic to bring those demons to light, because he wasn't afraid to direct a movie that inspired and terrified and shocked the world with its own beauty and brutality. Hacksaw ridge is both a nightmare and a dream.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Movie missed two elements that elevate Doss and his relationship with the men even further.
1) After being initially wounded, as seen in the movie, Doss was loaded onto a stretcher.  However, he rolled off it to treat another soldier.  Another wounded man was put on the stretcher.  Then Doss took a sniper's bullet that shattered his arm.  He splinted it and spent the next few hours getting himself off the field.
2) As to the lost Bible, Doss first realized it missing when aboard ship.  Word was sent to his unit of the loss and they searched throughout their battlefield before finding it.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I've seen "Hacksaw Ridge" and it was very inspirationally. I'm glad director, Mel Gibson come back for his directorial chair and he done a fantastic job for making an epic WWII film. Andrew Garfield did a fantastic job for portraying as Desmond Doss. A caring veteran who doesn't believe guns and his purpose is to safe many soldiers which takes place in Japan. His performance was very intense and maybe, he could be position in the Oscars, but only if they decision because he done amazing job. Not as much of being a weak superhero character in "The Amazing Spider-Man 2," but in the good position which I'll be in the next future films. The entire battleground sequence is pretty bloody and reminds like another epic mature war sequence like "Saving Private Ryan" and our main character focuses his job to save many soldiers as he can. This film is very brilliant and I'm glad I wasn't that much hyped and it takes patience without these moron commenters and critics alike. But, I only stood watching this film and one of the best films of 2016.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Excruciating,  brutal, dark, intense, gripping, but also well thought out and breathtaking this movie shows why we need Mel Gibson as director today. This film doesn't hold grudges, it is hardcore in your face brutality, but he wanted to show all horrors and pain these conflicts bring and boy did he succeeded in that.
Everything is worth of admiration here. Phenomenal performances, especially Hugo Weaving who was on fire in this and astonishing Andrew Garfield, great directing, visual storytelling, awesome special effects and huge props to sound mixers and sound editors because they've done magnificent job in transporting us into the heart of the battle. It is sometimes tough film to sit through, but not without well paced humour, sense of catharsis and spirituality. 
If there are gripes about the film it is that some aspects were little bit cliche, especially romance part and some parts of the battle felt exaggerated to pump that american patriotism. In the end Hacksaw Ridge is not recruitment propaganda, it doesn't try to indoctrinate you to become adventist or shove some crazy ideas into your mind. It is just inspirational, full of hope and strong spirit that always overcomes the depression and that place when people are at their lowest. 4,5/5

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
In honour of remembrance day, I went and watched "Hacksaw Ridge" at the theatre Friday night with some friends. 

I thought it was going to be good, but that's an understatement; 

WOW what a movie!

It's my 2nd favourite movie of the year hands down, and so fitting for what's going on in our world today.

There are so many levels to it that I was able to connect with and apply to my own life which I seem to do from any thing I watch or read these days. 

With never having served in the Canadian military, I truly can never fully understand or appreciate what men and woman have to go thru in war. I have the utmost respect for any human willing to lay their life on the line for their country and communities, military/police/fire fighters etc. 

Even though there are many things that greatly saddens me within these institutions, especially the taking of human life, as I believe all life is precious; no one deserves to have their life taken too soon. I do believe in justice and I believe the best system we can have here for that, is some type of prison system where the person has lost their freedom to do what they want. Maybe for more severe crimes more sever prisons....Siberia/The Arctic spring to mind. haha

But it saddens me that so many people will disrespect and burn their countries flag without having a healthy perspective of what their fellow countrymen go thru in trying to serve and protect the best way they know how, even if it is misguided at times. Sure we got good and bad soldiers, cops etc, but we should never blame all for evil of some. There is a reason the divorce rate is the highest amongst marriages that involve those who server in military or some form of police. The trauma and things they have to see, do and go thru, it can easily break your mind/heart. In the USA, 20-22 vets commit suicide every day, so these are serious issues.

We are a broken world filled with angry people and thats what we see and feel throughout history. And you especially see that anger in war and where those who are supposed to serve and protect you are the very ones who are hurting and abusing you. But like the movie illustrates, you can coward and blame others or you can do your best to fight for whats right, even when you feel the whole world is against you.

What is the answer to all that? 

For me it's walking in my faith, and that was one of the most amazing theme's of Hacksaw Ridge. How no matter the obstacle, how serious, life and death the situation was, he relied on his faith and it got him threw it; even though sometimes it wasn't till the last second! He didn't blame others for the problems of the world, he just wanted to serve and save lives the best way he knew how. 

He lead by example even though he took the beatings the world threw at him from his dad, his own military, to the Japanese, all who wanted to hurt him and even kill him. By leading by example, others wanted to now come up to his level instead of him coming down to theirs. You see this near the end of the movie in the most amazing way.

Spoiler alert...so dont read any further if you are going to go see it, but to see his fellow soldiers wait on going up the ridge for the next assault, because they saw the protection and blessing that God had on his life, they wanted his prayers because it was a miracle what he did the night before!

Before that day, they had assault after assault and failed miserably, with endless dead bodies and a demoralized people. After his prayers, well the American army finally took Hacksaw Ridge. It reminds so much of the old Testament and when God walked with Israel and they succeeded in their battles and when they didn't, their enemies won the battle. 

James 5:16...... and pray one for another, that ye may be healed. The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much.

One person can always make a difference, and one person walking with God can change the world! 

By his faith, he walked the walk, loved and served and what happened......GOD SHOWED UP!

GO WATCH THE MOVIE, honour our vets and get some perspective on what God can do when you put your faith in His ways instead of mans ways.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s2-1hz1juBI

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: My hubby and I went on Veteran's Day and it was a GREAT movie and should win many awards IMO!  I want my teens to see it who just watched Saving Private Ryan and we are about to start on Band of Brothers (I homeschool and am a WW2 history buff).  We don't go to the movies much but this movie  was worth it.    Both my grandfather's and my husband's grandfathers served in WW2.  My maternal grandfather served in Africa, Italy and Europe under Patton and won 2 Bronze Stars and was three days behind the Battle of the Bulge.  My husband's paternal grandfather was a lifer in the Army serving in the European Theater of WW2, Korea and Vietnam and his maternal grandfather saw the flag raised on Iwo Jima.   They have all passed onto Heaven, but I miss The Greatest Generation.  God Bless our Vets!  And God Bless America!

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: Thank you to Mel Gibson for making this amazing film on an amazing person of faith. Especially loved the moment of decision at the top of Hacksaw Ridge where he's praying about what to do next and the scenes that follow that. Though I found the scenes of war confronting, I later felt that they were important for knowing not only what soldiers go through and why so many struggle with PTSD afterwards, but also for knowing what Desmond was facing when he made the decision that he did that later brought him his Medal of Honour. Great directing with a real knowledge of where the emotional beats lay in the script and brilliant acting by a talented cast. Definitely want to see it again!

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: On this Veteran's Day, I met up with an old sailor, with whom I used to work, who is 71 years old now.  I'm an old sailor myself, who is 59 years old.  The military may seem to be about man's inhumanity to man, "homo homini lupus", "man is a wolf to man", as the ancient Romans put it in latin, but ultimately, the military is about man's humanity to man.  Ask the old GI's of WWII how it was when they, in later years, as tourists, met the old German soldiers, against whom they had fought.  Under those circumstances, it is more likely to be tears that are exchanged than bullets.  Ultimately, we do have our humanity.  Even soldiers and sailors.

Comment:
This movie was really really bad.
I can't understand the reviews it's getting. Nothing wrong with the reglious message or Mel Gibson himself. 
Just really terrible acting and horrible effects. Also very stupid moments in the film that were just so...random and out of place. 

The battle scenes were not even close to being realistic. Everybody just went total Rambo lol. Gore and the sounds were pretty good but that's about it lol.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Fuck this movie. I just came from the theater and it was so... idk. I was expecting religion to be theme. I was totally ok with that. I was not expecting religion being shoved down my throat at literally every 5 minutes or less. "Bible. Lord. Jesus. Pray. Pray. Pray. Bible. Bible". You could make a drinking game and get wasted in the first 10-15 minutes.

2 hours in three words: god, blood, and gore. It's well filmed and all, and there is a pretty good message, but it has too much propaganda covering it. The propaganda ruined the movie for me. Right now I am thinking "This movie's message wasn't about religion", but it's very hard to see that. This movie is made for religious people and to get admiration and viewers. Period. It's not even close to Braveheart.

Comment: This movie is fuckin amazing. Something cool happened when I went to the theatres. I'm waiting for my 10:30 show (730 sold out 4 hours before) and I'm sitting there blazed outta my mind with my Dasani water and pretzel bites with cheese. Then the 730 people come out and it's mostly elderly folks. They were so astonished and so hype about this movie, saying it was fantastic , unbelievable etc. and it just warmed my heart. They know what the WW2 war meant to them, same way when younger guys like me watch united 93 or the hurt locker. Just seeing that the movie made them so happy , was a really cool moment. Can't imagine what is was like to live in that time.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
this movie was ok. i went in this movie expecting to see about how desmond doss was like on the battlefield. the movie was great in the beginning but when it finally came to the war it turned around and was all about the war and not desmond and i think that the whole glorifying the war was unnecessary. we could of gone an hour without the blood and guts. i wanted to see more of desmond rescuing his comrades. if i wanted to see a war film then i would see a movie about war. this movie was supposed to be about desmond and it did not show how he got his medical training. was he supposed to automatically know what to do. desmond himself is a great man a true hero. this movie made me jump twice. andrew garfield did a good job. vince vaughn did an excellent job. i would say he almost stole the film. "get going private private 
parts" everything he said was funny but serious as well. i would like to see him in more roles like this. the story was amazing, the acting was great and the whole thing of standing up for what you believe in was great. the only reason i do not give this movie a higher rating is because they turned it into a war film not a film about desmond. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend you do or  rating 3/5

Hacksaw Ridge 9/10

The film is based on the true story of US Army medic Desmond T. Doss. Doss was a Seventh-day Adventist conscientious objector who refused to bear arms, yet was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Harry S. Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I hate it because the trailer frames his refusal to carry a weapon like it means something on the whole. If he just missed his shots during the war, it wouldn't have made a difference. But no, instead of just being one of the men, he has to get his microdick out and challenge everyone to measure up. All he had to do is not shoot when he should. Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: I did a report on Desmond Doss in middle school. Not only did Doss become one of the 464 Medal of Honor recipients of World War II but became the first conscientious objector to receive the Medal of Honor. People think that a hero may be someone that storms into a battlefield firing a rifle at anyone that's firing at their side of the line. Yet people forget the other side of heroic actions. Doss made a stand not only in the war against opposing forces but back home when he fought to defend his religion. I certainly plan on seeing this movie when it comes out.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I have known about this real character for some time. When I first came across his story, I decided to do research in order to find out if he really existed and if what I had initially heard had any merit in fact. What I discovered exceeded the initial account about his life I had heard. His whole life was a walking contradiction to the world in which he lived. This man's character and actions as a whole is legendary in the most positive sense of the word. How he was able to live in this world and make it to the end of a long life span is really remarkable because of how he demonstrated through daily action what he said he believed. It is curious how his story is only really known to a specific community of people in our world. This movie appears to finally bring his miraculous life and integrity to a greater audience. It is incongruous that his story is being revealed on a big stage in our society and culture at this distressing time in our country and world. However, his life as he lived it was incongruous with the world and time in which he was living.  We need more people to imitate this man's life.

This trailer appears to get the facts right as far as it can in a trailer. In order to fully appreciate this movie and understand the nuances I saw in the trailer and therefore believe will be in the movie, I suggest you web search Desmond T. Doss. I think that by learning everything you can about him will greatly enhance your experience as you watch the movie. If you don't, I think the amazing things you hear and see in the movie will cause you to greatly question the credibility of this being a true story.  Many comments I read make assumptions from this trailer that are fact incorrect.

I think the quality of this trailer really speaks for itself. It shows great cinematography, a good script, good acting, and potentially a well edited story line. I am not a member of the specific community from which this man came. However, I strive to be his brother in the community in which I believe he is a great example. I intentionally attempt not to reveal to much about Desmond T. Doss. I believe he is a man that deserves being discovered by each individual. If you are interested in being blessed by getting as close as you can to someone of great integrity and stability in this time of chaos and division, than he is worth putting in the time of researching him and seeing this movie.

Also, this story is not about Mel Gibson.  If you don't want to support or be connected to another human who you don't agree with, try disconnecting.  To be clear of my point, it is not possible to do.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: I knew this man and he was an incredible person. I met him at my local church when I was six. He was very healthy for his age and walked around well. He told me to shake his hand and I was afraid I would hurt it so I barely gave him a handshake, he told me to give him a real handshake not like a wet noodle. He would tell stories about the Navajo code breakers, guys that were teenagers in the war. He was strict, but kind and wise. I'm saddened by his passing this year. He was born in 1914 or 1915 and lived a long life. I've met his son also, a very nice man that has played drums for The Who and many other bands. He also became a pastor.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
It occurred to me that the negative comments are completely expected. 

These people only saw the trailer and drew some legitimates observations and concerns. However, I invite all the critics to read more into the real Desmond T Doss, the humble, unassuming man who just wanted to serve while holding dear to his faith at all cost. It's fascinating that some of the negative comments reflect the actual cynicism Doss' fellow soldiers and superiors showed towards him as well. They threw boots at him in the barracks, shamed him, called him cowards, made him clean the latrine, even tried to kick him out and threatened to kill him! When those very same men nominated Doss for nothing less than the Medal of Honor, and when surviving WWII MOH recipients appointed Doss to represent them in 1962 at the White House, their loathing had turned to respect for the man beyond reproach....and you would discover a man of biblical proportions. 

"But the Lord hath chosen the foolish things of the world to confound the wise; and the Lord hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things."
"Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends."

I, for one, am humbled and am truly privileged to have discovered Desmond Doss. All my complains, whining, hurt feelings, and vindictiveness are suddenly nonsensical. I can't help but being inspired to be a better, truer person.  I wished I had met him. He had led a quiet life in a town next to mine until his passing in March 23, 2006. A true soldier, and a saint.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
I'm going to get a lot of hate for this, but here we go:
(Sarcastic Trigger Warning: This post acknowledges that the world is a violent place)

Something people in today's society do not understand is that people must die for others to live. Though we can acknowledge that such a figure as "Pvt. Doss" is incredibly heroic and should be commended for their valor, this is not a message or a goal for all of our soldiers. This case study is not widely applicable to the vast majority of soldiers, especially those whose military occupational specialties are in combat arms. 

There are a number of military occupational specialties that allow individuals to serve without firing a shot. Except for the Marine Corps, which expects all of its service members to function in the capacity of a rifleman and their own specific MOS, every branch of the military offers non-combat roles that allow individuals to serve their country without killing anyone.

This film is not necessarily a social justice warrior piece of propaganda. Such a story is incredibly moving and can certainly serve to display the struggles of our brave servicemen. That said, if it overly brutalizes or crudely displays the personalities and actions of the soldiers, then it probably is. But don't make assumptions.

The reason I'm writing this is because I don't want a bunch of idealists in our military. With Trump or Clinton at the helm, you should expect to get your hands dirty if you're in combat arms. While we can afford a Pvt. Doss here and there, an army of pacifists has never won a war. And to the special snowflakes reading this comment: MLK and Gandhi didn't fight wars. They had struggles, but there was no concentrated military effort seeking to capture, kill, or destroy them. 

That said, I hope this film isn't turned into SJW bullshit and I also hope that not too many soldiers and conservatives dismiss this movie before they see it. Peace out.(see what I did there?)

Comment: I read the book about Cpl. Doss...talk about insane shit!! A japanese sniper wrote after the war that he had Cpl. Doss in his sights at least three times...and every time his gun jammed or wouldn't fire for some reason...I'm sorry, but's that not a coincidence. THREE purple hearts (one of which came from the grenade scene which tore the hell out of his legs), another time shot in the arm by a sniper that practically shattered his left arm. Two silver stars and the Medal of Honor...and never fired a single round...FUCK ME that's insane!!!!! Unfortunately, men like these hardly exist today...RIP Cpl. Doss d.2006

So America's greatest hero of the Greatest Generation was a total pussy who wouldn't pick up a rifle to save his own life, the lives of his best friends, of the lives of the millions of victims of the Axis powers. This movie lionizes his "courage" to be a coward. I would have kicked him in the face, too. I don't want a teammate who would rather watch me be run through by a katana on the battlefield than pick up a weapon to defend me. This man and men like him could never have defeated Nazi Germany. It took guts, grit, as the determination to do the ugly and unpleasant violent work of stopping evil by force. His immoral attitude is to tolerate evil. I don't ever want to kill anyone, either,
but I'm willing to do things I don't want
to do to stop great evils like mass murder. I miss old-fashioned American values. Hollywood movies and TV today glamorize being a selfish wimp.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Below is the citation for why Desmond (character film is based on) received Medal of Honor-medal, read and cry. 

He was a company aid man when the 1st Battalion assaulted a jagged escarpment 400 feet high. As our troops gained the summit, a heavy concentration of artillery, mortar and machinegun fire crashed into them, inflicting approximately 75 casualties and driving the others back. Pfc. Doss refused to seek cover and remained in the fire-swept area with the many stricken, carrying all 75 casualties one-by-one to the edge of the escarpment and there lowering them on a rope-supported litter down the face of a cliff to friendly hands. On May 2, he exposed himself to heavy rifle and mortar fire in rescuing a wounded man 200 yards forward of the lines on the same escarpment; and 2 days later he treated 4 men who had been cut down while assaulting a strongly defended cave, advancing through a shower of grenades to within eight yards of enemy forces in a cave's mouth, where he dressed his comrades' wounds before making 4 separate trips under fire to evacuate them to safety. On May 5, he unhesitatingly braved enemy shelling and small arms fire to assist an artillery officer. He applied bandages, moved his patient to a spot that offered protection from small arms fire and, while artillery and mortar shells fell close by, painstakingly administered plasma. Later that day, when an American was severely wounded by fire from a cave, Pfc. Doss crawled to him where he had fallen 25 feet from the enemy position, rendered aid, and carried him 100 yards to safety while continually exposed to enemy fire. On May 21, in a night attack on high ground near Shuri, he remained in exposed territory while the rest of his company took cover, fearlessly risking the chance that he would be mistaken for an infiltrating Japanese and giving aid to the injured until he was himself seriously wounded in the legs by the explosion of a grenade. Rather than call another aid man from cover, he cared for his own injuries and waited 5 hours before litter bearers reached him and started carrying him to cover. The trio was caught in an enemy tank attack and Pfc. Doss, seeing a more critically wounded man nearby, crawled off the litter; and directed the bearers to give their first attention to the other man. Awaiting the litter bearers' return, he was again struck, by a sniper bullet while being carried off the field by a comrade, this time suffering a compound fracture of 1 arm. With magnificent fortitude he bound a rifle stock to his shattered arm as a splint and then crawled 300 yards over rough terrain to the aid station. Through his outstanding bravery and unflinching determination in the face of desperately dangerous conditions Pfc. Doss saved the lives of many soldiers. His name became a symbol throughout the 77th Infantry Division for outstanding gallantry far above and beyond the call of duty.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Here is his Medal of Honor Citation:
The President of the United States in the name of The Congress takes pleasure in presenting the Medal of Honor to
DOSS, DESMOND T.
Rank and organization: Private First Class, U.S. Army, Medical Detachment, 
307th Infantry, 77th Infantry Division. Place and date: Near Urasoe 
Mura, Okinawa, Ryukyu Islands, 29 April-21 May 1945. Entered service at:
 Lynchburg, Va. Birth: Lynchburg, Va. G.O. No.: 97, 1 November 1945. 
Citation:
 He was a company aid man when the 1st Battalion assaulted a jagged 
escarpment 400 feet high As our troops gained the summit, a heavy 
concentration of artillery, mortar and machinegun fire crashed into 
them, inflicting approximately 75 casualties and driving the others 
back. Pfc. Doss refused to seek cover and remained in the fire-swept 
area with the many stricken, carrying them 1 by 1 to the edge of the 
escarpment and there lowering them on a rope-supported litter down the 
face of a cliff to friendly hands. On 2 May, he exposed himself to heavy
 rifle and mortar fire in rescuing a wounded man 200 yards forward of 
the lines on the same escarpment; and 2 days later he treated 4 men who 
had been cut down while assaulting a strongly defended cave, advancing 
through a shower of grenades to within 8 yards of enemy forces in a 
cave's mouth, where he dressed his comrades' wounds before making 4 
separate trips under fire to evacuate them to safety. On 5 May, he 
unhesitatingly braved enemy shelling and small arms fire to assist an 
artillery officer. He applied bandages, moved his patient to a spot that
 offered protection from small arms fire and, while artillery and mortar
 shells fell close by, painstakingly administered plasma. Later that 
day, when an American was severely wounded by fire from a cave, Pfc. 
Doss crawled to him where he had fallen 25 feet from the enemy position,
 rendered aid, and carried him 100 yards to safety while continually 
exposed to enemy fire. On 21 May, in a night attack on high ground near 
Shuri, he remained in exposed territory while the rest of his company 
took cover, fearlessly risking the chance that he would be mistaken for 
an infiltrating Japanese and giving aid to the injured until he was 
himself seriously wounded in the legs by the explosion of a grenade. 
Rather than call another aid man from cover, he cared for his own 
injuries and waited 5 hours before litter bearers reached him and 
started carrying him to cover. The trio was caught in an enemy tank 
attack and Pfc. Doss, seeing a more critically wounded man nearby, 
crawled off the litter; and directed the bearers to give their first 
attention to the other man. Awaiting the litter bearers' return, he was 
again struck, this time suffering a compound fracture of 1 arm. With 
magnificent fortitude he bound a rifle stock to his shattered arm as a 
splint and then crawled 300 yards over rough terrain to the aid station.
 Through his outstanding bravery and unflinching determination in the 
face of desperately dangerous conditions Pfc. Doss saved the lives of 
many soldiers. His name became a symbol throughout the 77th Infantry 
Division for outstanding gallantry far above and beyond the call of 
duty.

Comment: Strange guy, really weird idea to promote it. Obama style - Ukrainians should fight for their freedom and lives but without lethal weapons (jerk). I've read the memories of young soviet Jew, who joint the partisans in Bryansk region during WW2. Astonishing story, once he was caught by polizai (Russians who supported Germans) they where too busy, the weather was bad (blizzard) so they shoot him in the back, but the wound was light. In few moths he met those polizai in convoy ambushed. He said that it was surprisingly easy (for 16 year boy) how quickly and easy he killed 4 armed men with dagger jumping in their wagon from the roof of the barn. During breaking from encirclement by regular German units. his detachment was forced to cross the road - 100 m of open place close to German  positions. 2 machine guns provided covering fire taking all enemy fire without any cover - 12 machine gunners where killed one after one, he was second in the line to replace dead gunners when convoy crossed the road. True stories which are much more amazing than any Hollywood screenplays.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
ank and organization: Private First Class, United States Army, Medical Detachment, 307th Infantry, 77th Infantry Division.
Place and date: Near Urasoe Mura, Okinawa, Ryukyu Islands, April 29, 1945Â â€“ May 21, 1945.
Entered service at: Lynchburg, Virginia
Birth: Lynchburg, Virginia
G.O. No.: 97, November 1, 1945.

 


Doss receiving the Medal of Honor from President Harry Truman


Citation
 

He was a company aid man when the 1st Battalion assaulted a jagged escarpment 400 feet high. As our troops gained the summit, a heavy concentration of artillery, mortar and machinegun
 fire crashed into them, inflicting approximately 75 casualties and 
driving the others back. Pfc. Doss refused to seek cover and remained in
 the fire-swept area with the many stricken, carrying all 75 casualties 
one-by-one to the edge of the escarpment and there lowering them on a 
rope-supported litter down the face of a cliff to friendly hands. On May
 2, he exposed himself to heavy rifle and mortar fire in rescuing a 
wounded man 200 yards forward of the lines on the same escarpment; and 2
 days later he treated 4 men who had been cut down while assaulting a 
strongly defended cave, advancing through a shower of grenades
 to within eight yards of enemy forces in a cave's mouth, where he 
dressed his comrades' wounds before making 4 separate trips under fire 
to evacuate them to safety. On May 5, he unhesitatingly braved enemy 
shelling and small arms fire to assist an artillery officer. He applied 
bandages, moved his patient to a spot that offered protection from small
 arms fire and, while artillery and mortar shells fell close by, 
painstakingly administered plasma.
 Later that day, when an American was severely wounded by fire from a 
cave, Pfc. Doss crawled to him where he had fallen 25 feet from the 
enemy position, rendered aid, and carried him 100 yards to safety while 
continually exposed to enemy fire. On May 21, in a night attack on high 
ground near Shuri, he remained in exposed territory while the rest of 
his company took cover, fearlessly risking the chance that he would be 
mistaken for an infiltrating Japanese and giving aid to the injured 
until he was himself seriously wounded in the legs by the explosion of a
 grenade. Rather than call another aid man from cover, he cared for his 
own injuries and waited 5 hours before litter bearers reached him and started carrying him to cover. The trio was caught in an enemy tank
 attack and Pfc. Doss, seeing a more critically wounded man nearby, 
crawled off the litter; and directed the bearers to give their first 
attention to the other man. Awaiting the litter bearers' return, he was 
again struck, by a sniper bullet while being carried off the field by a 
comrade, this time suffering a compound fracture of 1 arm. With magnificent fortitude he bound a rifle stock to his shattered arm as a splint
 and then crawled 300 yards over rough terrain to the aid station. 
Through his outstanding bravery and unflinching determination in the 
face of desperately dangerous conditions Pfc. Doss saved the lives of 
many soldiers. His name became a symbol throughout the 77th Infantry 
Division for outstanding gallantry far above and beyond the call of 
duty.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Desmond T. Doss

He was a company aid man when the 1st Battalion assaulted a jagged escarpment 400 feet high. As our troops gained the summit, a heavy concentration of artillery, mortar and machine gun fire crashed into them, inflicting approximately 75 casualties and driving the others back. Pfc. Doss refused to seek cover and remained in the fire-swept area with the many stricken, carrying all 75 casualties one-by-one to the edge of the escarpment and there lowering them on a rope-supported litter down the face of a cliff to friendly hands. On May 2, he exposed himself to heavy rifle and mortar fire in rescuing a wounded man 200 yards forward of the lines on the same escarpment; and 2 days later he treated 4 men who had been cut down while assaulting a strongly defended cave, advancing through a shower of grenades to within eight yards of enemy forces in a cave's mouth, where he dressed his comrades' wounds before making 4 separate trips under fire to evacuate them to safety. On May 5, he unhesitatingly braved enemy shelling and small arms fire to assist an artillery officer. He applied bandages, moved his patient to a spot that offered protection from small arms fire and, while artillery and mortar shells fell close by, painstakingly administered plasma. Later that day, when an American was severely wounded by fire from a cave, Pfc. Doss crawled to him where he had fallen 25 feet from the enemy position, rendered aid, and carried him 100 yards to safety while continually exposed to enemy fire. On May 21, in a night attack on high ground near Shuri, he remained in exposed territory while the rest of his company took cover, fearlessly risking the chance that he would be mistaken for an infiltrating Japanese and giving aid to the injured until he was himself seriously wounded in the legs by the explosion of a grenade. Rather than call another aid man from cover, he cared for his own injuries and waited 5 hours before litter bearers reached him and started carrying him to cover. The trio was caught in an enemy tank attack and Pfc. Doss, seeing a more critically wounded man nearby, crawled off the litter; and directed the bearers to give their first attention to the other man. Awaiting the litter bearers' return, he was again struck, by a sniper bullet while being carried off the field by a comrade, this time suffering a compound fracture of 1 arm. With magnificent fortitude he bound a rifle stock to his shattered arm as a splint and then crawled 300 yards over rough terrain to the aid station. Through his outstanding bravery and unflinching determination in the face of desperately dangerous conditions Pfc. Doss saved the lives of many soldiers. His name became a symbol throughout the 77th Infantry Division for outstanding gallantry far above and beyond the call of duty. He also received the medal of honor.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment:
Sigh... I gotta clarify this for many guys posting comments here without reading about Desmond Doss.
(1) It's not a fictional story - go watch "The Conscientious Objector", a documentary featuring interviews of Desmond Doss' teammates and himself. He was a Seventh-day Adventist who firmly believed in keeping God's commandment "Thou shalt not kill".
(2) Desmond Doss actually did kick the grenade, so don't go thinking that scene in the trailer was just to make it more "action-packed".
(3) "rescued 75 people single-handedly" was just the officials giving an average number. His teammates said he saved about 100 people all by himself, but Desmond said "it couldn't have been more than 50" so they took the average (50+100)/2=75.
(4) Desmond Doss died in 2006.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016) Official Trailer â€“ â€œBelieveâ€ - Andrew Garfield
Comment: Drafted in April 1942,  Desmond Doss (Medal of Honor Recipient) refused to kill or carry a weapon into combat because of his personal beliefs as a Seventh-day Adventist. He consequently became a medic, and while serving in the Pacific Theatre of World War II he helped his country by saving the lives of his comrades, at the same time adhering to his religious convictions. Doss was wounded three times during the war, and shortly before leaving the Army he was diagnosed with tuberculosis, which cost him a lung. Discharged from the Army in 1946,he spent five years undergoing medical treatment for his injuries and illness.

Comment: He never wanted his story to come to the screen in life. I hope this is not something he would disapprove of. Still, how inspiring a story this will be. For those that don't know, Doss was a Seventh Day Adventist and conscientious objector. He refused to touch weapons, even to defend himself, due to his religious beliefs. However, he certainly showed no cowardice. He only ever used a weapon to splint his leg or arm so that he could continue to rescue his fallen brothers after he himself was wounded.  I'm glad his story will become common knowledge.

Comment:
Holy crap this looks remarkable, it gave me chills man, and I'm not even from the US.  It's so great to have Mel Gibson behind the cameras again, the guy is a fantastic director, and the script was written by the same guys who wrote Braveheart,  so just shut the fuck up and take my money.

As for Mel personal affairs, I can totally separate the artist from the person (I freaking love Wagner and Lovecraft work knowing how much of an assholes they were), but in this case, I think he regret was he has done in the past, and that good for me, I'm not a christian myself but I do believe that we can forgive someone who is truly regretful of his actions.
